title: Directory Services
description: A Directory Service is a shared information infrastructure for locating, managing, administering and organizing everyday items and network resources, which can include volumes, folders, files, printers, users, groups, devices, telephone numbers and other objects.
key-ideas: Directory Services are databases which are used to store, describe, and manage information on network resources and entities such as users, computers, printers, network volumes, groups.
The X.500 specification is the most common format for access directory services.
LDAP, based on the X.500 specification, is the most often used protocol to access directory services information over TCP/IP.
LDAP operates on port 389 for unencrypted connections.
LDAPS (TLS encrypted LDAP connections) operate on port 636.
Directory Services is often used in conjunction with identity and access management (IAM), identity federation, single sign-on, and device and account management.
Common Directory Service entries are: user accounts, groups, computers, printers, network volumes.
